resources.string:
Miss Stats is the Statistics teacher everyone would be happy to meet, even who ignore what Statistics is. 
 Her mission is to spread the knowledge of Statistics everywhere with simple and effective words and above all with the help of many, many examples. 
 Once, many years ago, I told her (I even don't remember about what): 
 "Miss Stats, this is really impossible for me, this would never happen!", but she answered me, and I have never forgot it: 
 "Nothing is impossible. There are only things extremely improbable" and then she calculated with extremely precision what my chance were.
 No problem, big or small, can scare Miss Stats, her motto is always: 
 "Give me enough data and I will give you the solution".
 Numbers, according to Miss Stats, are very often undervalued, somebody think they are useful only for calculating results, but this isn't true: if you observe them with attention, like a true detective, they can tell you incredible stories and disclose entire secret worlds.
Follow Miss Stats through this app, you won\'t regret it!

According to Miss Stats, Statistics is the science that transforms huge collections of data, numerical and not numerical, in something that makes sense for a normal human being, something that can tell you a story. 
 The first thing to do in Statistics is always the same: collect data, because data are the basis for every statistical story. That's why statisticians ask people so many strange questions, like: 
 "What is your favorite ice cream flavor?" 
 "Do you buy more ice cream in summer or in winter?" 
 Statisticians fill pages and pages of data, they study them from every point of view, they draw graphics showing the most preferred ice-creams and how many ice-creams are sold in every season. 
 With data at hand, statisticians pass to the second phase: they must interpret the data, that's to say they must give them a meaning. This is the most difficult moment, the moment that divides artists (like Miss Stats) from amateurs. 
 A statistical story could tell: "Most of people eat much more ice-cream in Summer, especially chocolate and vanilla". This kind of stories are really important: they are used to make things work properly. 
 Imagine a world where the ice-cream flavors in your most trusted ice cream shop are decided by pure randomness and not by science.
 Terrible things could happen! In Summer your local vendor could run out of chocolate and vanilla ice creams. 
Do you know which are the feelings of someone who wants a chocolate ice cream and finds only carrot and broccoli ice creams? I suppose you don't: well, you can thank Statistics for this.
